Education: Learned how to do research.  Made some great friends.  Met my wife.  It was a wonderful four years.  Details were published as a book, so I'll keep this description short.

One of the brave, the proud, the few (< 100) graduates of this fine but short-lived institution.   The innovative curriculum combined deep technical classes taught by leading computer science researchers with project management and  "mini-MBA" courses.   This is a model that is resurfacing in many professional Masters programs, such as the new MEng program at Berkeley.   One cool fact - students were required to have at least two years professional programming experience before they could be admitted.

Where I learned the foundations of what I do professionally, and through a series of fortunate events got involved in my first database systems research project.   I also was able to spend a year studying and traveling abroad, which started a fascination with travel that continues today.   Any students reading this - I strongly advise you to make the time to take advantage of study abroad and exchange programs at your school.
